headline: Vance leads Senate GOP primary field in Ohio: poll
author: Tal Axelrod
sentences: Observers questioned whether Trumps backers would be cool to Vance over critical comments he made in 2016 about the real estate moguls White House bid, but Trump sought to tamp down any lingering disgruntlement in his endorsement.

Vance has looked to saturate voters minds with news of the endorsement by appearing at a rally last weekend with Trump and also holding several events with Donald Trump Jr., the former presidents eldest son.

But still, the poll marks a significant improvement for Vance, who is waging a full court press to inundate voters with news of Trumps endorsement, which came on April 15, shortly before the May 3 primary.

Ohio GOP Senate candidate JD Vance leads the Republican primary field in a new Fox News poll released Tuesday, an indication that hes enjoying a boost from a late endorsement from former President Trump.
Vance had previously been polling in the middle of the field, but a survey from a supportive super PAC released last week also showed him jumping into the lead after winning Trumps backing.
Investment banker Mike Gibbons, state Sen. Matt Dolan and former Ohio GOP Chair Jane Timken rounded out the top five, with 13 percent support, 11 percent and 6 percent, respectively.
Vance, the author of Hillbilly Elegy,? led the pack with 23 percent support primary voters, more than doubling the 11 percent support he got in the same poll in March.
The winner of the GOP primary is expected to take on Rep. Tim Ryan, the prohibitive favorite in the Democratic primary, in the general election later this year.
Forty-two percent of primary voters said his imprimatur makes them more supportive of Vance, while just 23 percent said it made them less supportive.
Former state Treasurer Josh Mandel, Vances main primary rival, came in second with 18 percent, a drop from 20 percent in March.
Gibbonss support nosedived from 22 percent in March, while Dolans rose from 7 percent and Timkens dropped from 9 percent.
The Hill has removed its comment section, as there are many other forums for readers to participate in the conversation.
Vance may have said some not so great things about me in the past, but he gets it now, and I have seen that in spades.
In a sign the race remains in flux, 25 percent of voters  a plurality in the poll  said they remain undecided.
Those numbers indicated that Vance improvement likely came mostly from voters who previously backed Gibbons.
The poll, which was conducted April 20-24, included 906 randomly selected Ohio Republican primary voters.
Fifty-one percent of respondents who said they back a candidate also said they could change their minds.
Trump won Ohio twice by about 8 points and remains overwhelmingly popular with Republicans.
He is our best chance for victory in what could be a very tough race,? Trump said.
It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

Another 27 percent said the endorsement had no effect.
